abstract.text: Create cross-platform desktop apps for macOS, Linux, Windows, iOS and tvOS.

inlineContent.text: SwiftCrossUI takes inspiration from SwiftUI, allowing you to use the basic concepts of SwiftUI to create cross-platform desktop apps. SwiftCrossUI provides your users with a native experience on every platform via a suite of backends built on top of various UI frameworks (see

abstract.text: SwiftCrossUI has a variety of backends tailored to different operating systems. The beauty of SwiftCrossUI is that you can write your app once and have it look native everywhere. For this reason I recommend using
unless you’ve got particular constraints.
The top level of your app.
The wide variety of views available that you can combine to create complex UIs.
Objects that are read from and/or written to as part of your app.
The detailed components that are part of the low level of SwiftCrossUI.
Create cross-platform desktop apps for macOS, Linux, Windows, iOS and tvOS.
An alert action button. Only backends should interface with this type
directly. See
A builder for
The 2d alignment of a view.
A view which erases the type of its child. Useful in dynamic
use-cases such as hot reloading, but not recommended if there
are alternate strongly-typed solutions to your problem since
has significantly more overhead than strongly
typed views.
A type-erased
. Used by implementations of
to avoid leaking the selected backend into
implementations (which would be
an annoying complexity for users of the library and it worth the slight sacrifice
in performance and strong-typing). The user never sees such type-erased wrappers.
A type-erased widget which can be stored without having to propagate
the selected backend type through the type system of the whole view graph
system of types, which would leak it back into user view implementations
making the backend hard to switch for developers.
An application.
A backend that can be used to run an app (e.g. Gtk or Qt).
SwiftCrossUI’s native macOS backend built on AppKit.
Metadata loaded at app start up.
An axis in a 2D coordinate system.
A value that can read and write a value owned by a source of truth. Can be thought of
as a writable reference to the value.
A control that initiates an action.
Will run a ‘cancel’ action when the cancellable falls out of scope (gets
deinit’d by ARC). Protects against calling the action twice.
The position of a cell in a table (with row and column numbers starting from 0).
An RGBA representation of a color.
A builder for
A content type corresponding to a specific file/data format.
An adaptive backend which uses different backends under the hood depending on the target operating system.
A divider that expands along the minor axis of the containing stack layout
(or horizontally otherwise). In dark mode it’s white with 10% opacity, and
in light mode it’s black with 10% opacity.
A value convertible to and from a
A property wrapper updated by the view graph before each access to
. Conforming types should use internal mutability (see
to implement this protocol’s non-mutable methods if required. This
protocol avoids mutation to allow state properties and such to be
captured even though views are structs.
Indicates a specific edge of a rectangle.
A view used by
to support if/else conditional statements.
A placeholder view used by elementary
implementations which don’t have bodies. Fatally
crashes if rendered.
The children of a node with no children.
A property wrapper used to access environment values within a
or
. Must not be used before the view graph accesses the view or app’s
(i.e. don’t access it from an initializer).
A key that can be used to extend the environment with new properties.
The environment used when constructing scenes and views. Each scene or view
gets to modify the environment before passing it on to its children, which
is the basis of many view modifiers.
An overview of the examples included with SwiftCrossUI.
The result returned when a user either selects a file or dismisses the
file chooser dialog.
A view that displays a variable amount of children.
A view that groups views together without affecting their layout (allowing
modifiers to be applied to a whole group of views at once).
A secondary Linux backend built on Gtk 3 (for older distros without Gtk 4).
SwiftCrossUI’s native Linux backend built on Gtk 4.
A view that arranges its subviews horizontally.
Alignment of items layed out along the horizontal axis.
A view which attempts to persist the state of its view subtree even
when the subtree’s structure changes. Uses state serialization (via
view graph snapshotting) to persist view state even when a child
view’s implementation gets swapped out with an implementation from
a newly-loaded dylib (this is what makes this useful for hot reloading).
A view that displays an image.
The layout orientation inherited by a widget from its nearest oriented parent.
An item of a
or
A builder for
A navigation primitive that appends a value to the current navigation path on click.
A type-erased list of data representing the content of a navigation stack.
A view that presents views in two or three columns.
A view that displays a root view and enables you to present additional views over the root view.
An object that can be observed for changes.
Opens a URL with the default application. May present an application picker
if multiple applications are registered for the given URL protocol.
A view used by
to support non-exhaustive if statements.
The orientation of a view (usually in reference to a stack view).
A control for selecting from a set of values.
Presents an alert to the user. Returns once an action has been selected and
the corresponding action handler has been run. Returns the index of the
selected action. By default, the alert will have a single button labelled
. All buttons will dismiss the alert even if you provide your own
actions.
Presents a ‘Save file’ dialog fit for selecting a save destination. Returns
if the user cancels the operation.
Presents an ‘Open file’ dialog fit for selecting a single file. Some
backends only allow selecting either files or directories but not both
in a single dialog. Returns
if the user cancels the operation.
A wrapper which publishes a change whenever the wrapped value is set. If
the wrapped value is
, its
publisher will
also be forwarded to the wrapper’s publisher.
values nested within an
object
will only have their changes published by the parent
if marked with this marker protocol. This avoids uncertainty around which
properties will or will not have their changes published by the parent.
For clarity reasons, you shouldn’t conform your own types to this protocol.
Instead, apply the
property wrapper when needed.
A type that produces valueless observations.
Creating a cross-platform SwiftCrossUI app with Swift Bundler.
A generic representation of an application menu, pop-up menu, or context menu.
This is what eventually gets passed through to the backend.
A scene wraps a root view and dictates how it is displayed (e.g. in a window or
a menu bar). Scenes can also be a composition of multiple child scenes instead
of wrapping a root view.
Builds an app’s root scene by composing other scenes together.
A persistent representation of a scene that maintains its state even when the scene
itself gets recomputed. Required to store view graphs and widget handles etc.
A view that is scrollable when it would otherwise overflow available space. Use the
modifier to constrain height if necessary.
A control for selecting a value from a bounded range of numerical values.
A flexible space that expands along the major axis of its containing
stack layout, or on both axes if not contained in a stack.
Alignment of items layed out along either a horizontal or vertical axis.
A container that presents rows of data arranged in columns.
A labelled column with a view for each row in a table.
A result builder for constructing a collection of table columns.
A text view.
A control that displays an editable text interface.
A view with exactly 1 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A view with exactly 10 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A view with exactly 2 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A view with exactly 3 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A view with exactly 4 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A view with exactly 5 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A view with exactly 6 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A view with exactly 7 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A view with exactly 8 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A view with exactly 9 children. Autogenerated as an alternative to Swift’s not yet
production ready variadic generics.
A fixed-length strongly-typed collection of 1 child nodes. A counterpart to
A fixed-length strongly-typed collection of 10 child nodes. A counterpart to
A fixed-length strongly-typed collection of 2 child nodes. A counterpart to
A fixed-length strongly-typed collection of 3 child nodes. A counterpart to
A fixed-length strongly-typed collection of 4 child nodes. A counterpart to
A fixed-length strongly-typed collection of 5 child nodes. A counterpart to
A fixed-length strongly-typed collection of 6 child nodes. A counterpart to
A fixed-length strongly-typed collection of 7 child nodes. A counterpart to
A fixed-length strongly-typed collection of 8 child nodes. A counterpart to
A fixed-length strongly-typed collection of 9 child nodes. A counterpart to
SwiftCrossUI’s native iOS and tvOS backend built on UIKit.
A view that arranges its subviews vertically.
Alignment of items layed out along the vertical axis.
A view that can be rendered by any backend.
The view’s contents.
A result builder used to compose views together into composite views in
a declarative manner.
The root of the view graph which shadows a root view’s structure with extra metadata,
cross-update state persistence, and behind the scenes backend widget handling.
A view graph node storing a view, its widget, and its children (likely a collection of more nodes).
The children of a view graph node. This is implemented by a few different
types for various purposes. E.g. variable length with same-typed elements
), and fixed length with distinctly-typed elements (
, etc).
The size of a view. Includes ideal size, and minimum/maximum width and height
along with the size you’d expect.
SwiftCrossUI’s native Windows backend built on WinUI 3.
A scene that presents a group of identically structured windows. Currently
only supports having a single instance of the window but will eventually
support duplicating the window.
The
corresponding to a
scene. Holds
the scene’s view graph and window handle.
The level of resizability of a window.
